block.p: Nasdaq Increases Sharply In a Technology Rebound Technology stocks, under pressure for much of September, moved sharply higher, driving the Nasdaq composite index to its biggest one-day gain in more than three months. A good day in the bond market and a dip in oil prices provided a positive backdrop for stocks.

The Nasdaq composite index gained 139.12 points, or 3.7 percent, to 3,865.64. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 15.39 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,459.90, while the Dow Jones industrial average fell 19.23 points, or 0.2 percent, to 10,789.29. [Page C10.]

More Deaths Are Cited in Tire Case Federal regulators said that since Aug. 31 they had received complaints of 15 more deaths attributed to Firestone tires on sport utility vehicles and pickups, raising to 103 the number of deaths under review. But officials cautioned that they had not determined how many of the complaints involved tires that had failed. [C2.]

Sun to Buy Web Appliance Maker Sun Microsystems said that it had agreed to acquire Cobalt Networks, which produces Web appliances, in a stock swap valued at $2 billion. Acquiring Cobalt lets Sun address a fast-growing portion of the market that could not be reached readily with its own typically more expensive and more complex products. Shares of Sun gained $2.44, to $117.69, while Cobalt increased $16.06, or nearly 40 percent, to $57.19. [C9.]

U.S. Antitrust Chief to Step Down Joel I. Klein, the head of the Justice Department's antitrust division and chief architect of the government's case against Microsoft, announced that he would step down. [C2.]

Ads Bolster Retail Sales of Drugs Advertising to consumers has stimulated a surge in retail spending on prescription drugs, the fastest-growing item in the nation's health care budget, a new study says. [A18.]

Concessions Made for Joint Venture Time Warner and EMI Group proposed what they called ''substantial'' concessions that might include selling some of their record labels in an effort to keep European regulators from blocking their plan to merge their music businesses into a joint venture. [C9.]

Japan Prepares Spending Package Japan is preparing another package of supplemental spending aimed at propping up the economy, which has failed to gain enough momentum on its own despite several previous injections of money. [C4.]

American Works the Puzzle of China Being the general manager of Xerox's operations in China has required Howard Holley to make adjustments in the way he does business. But the business challenges are no greater than other puzzles he has faced there. Shanghai consistently exceeds expectations, he says. It's a city of dichotomies -- the extremes of China all rolled into one. He relishes the challenge. The Boss. [C8.]

Death on Plane Ruled a Homicide A passenger who tried to break into the cockpit during a Southwest Airlines flight was killed by passengers who restrained him, and not by a heart attack, as had been reported. A medical examiner ruled the death a homicide, but the authorities decided that there was no evidence of criminal intent and declined to bring charges. Joe Sharkey: Business Travel. [C5.]

Price of E-Book Device Set at $300 Thomson Multimedia has priced its hand-held devices for reading electronic books. At about $300, they are unlikely to speed the adoption of e-books by the mass market. [C5.]
